questions.question: Which of the following is a living thing?

answers.explanation: Dogs grow, need food and water, and can reproduce, so they are living.
Rocks do not grow, move on their own, or need food or water.
Toy cars are man-made objects that do not show the characteristics of life.
Pencils are non-living objects; they do not grow or reproduce.

questions.question: Which feature would help you decide that a plant is living?

answers.content: It changes and grows over time
answers.explanation: Growth is one of the key characteristics of living things.
Not everything green is alive, so colour alone is not enough.
Many non-living things are also found outdoors.
Sound does not determine if something is living or non-living.

questions.question: Name any two basic needs that all living things have.

answers.content: Shelter / a safe place to live

questions.question: Explain why a freshly picked flower is still considered a living thing.

answers.content: It is still carrying out life processes such as using stored food, responding to light, and its cells are alive, even though it has been removed from the plant.
answers.explanation: The flower’s cells are still alive and it can continue limited life activities (e.g. using water in its stem) for a while after being picked.

questions.question: During the lesson, which activity helped you observe living and non-living things in the school environment?

answers.content: Going on a guided walk and taking photos/drawings
answers.explanation: Students explored the school grounds to identify and record living and non-living things.
This was not an activity in the lesson.

answers.content: Playing a computer game about numbers
answers.explanation: This was not part of the science lesson.
This was not an activity related to observing living and non-living things.

questions.question: Draw one living thing and one non-living thing you saw on the school walk. Label each drawing and circle the living thing in blue and the non-living thing in red.

answers.content: Teacher-marked: Award 2 marks if both drawings are accurate, correctly labelled and circled with the correct colours.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four basic needs of all animals?

answers.explanation: While animals benefit from enrichment, toys are not a survival need like air, food, water and shelter.

questions.question: Pets often rely on their owners to provide them with shelter. Which of these items is an example of shelter for a dog?

answers.explanation: A kennel protects a dog from sun, rain and wind.

questions.question: Which pet from the list usually needs to go for walks every day?

answers.explanation: Dogs need regular exercise such as daily walks.

questions.question: In one or two sentences, explain why water is important for animals.

answers.content: Water helps animals digest food, keep their bodies at the right temperature and move nutrients around their bodies.

questions.question: Draw a picture of a pet showing how its basic needs of food, water and shelter are being met. Label each part of your drawing.
Which of these is a basic need of ALL plants?

answers.explanation: Plants use sunlight to perform photosynthesis and make their own food.

questions.question: In the lesson’s two photos of the same plant, what happened after the plant received water?

answers.content: Its leaves stood up and looked healthy again.
answers.explanation: Water helped the wilted plant become firm and green.

answers.content: It turned into a different plant.

questions.question: In the cress-seed investigation, which variable was different between the two cups?

answers.content: Amount of light each cup received
answers.explanation: One cup was placed in sunlight while the other was kept in the dark.

answers.content: Amount of water each cup received

questions.question: Write TWO things plants need to stay alive.

answers.content: Water and sunlight (other valid answers: air, nutrients, space)
answers.explanation: The lesson focused on water and sunlight as the two most obvious needs.

questions.question: Why do plants need sunlight?

answers.content: To make their own food during photosynthesis
answers.explanation: Sunlight provides the energy plants use to turn water and carbon dioxide into glucose.

questions.question: During the ‘act it out’ activity, what was the watering can pretending to give the thirsty plant?

answers.explanation: The role-play reinforced that plants need water to survive.

questions.question: Draw a young plant and show the TWO main things it needs to live and grow.

answers.content: Student should depict a plant receiving sunlight and water (e.g., rays from a sun and drops from a watering can/cloud).
answers.explanation: Drawing must clearly represent both water and sunlight for full marks.

questions.question: The photo of the patchy lawn showed yellow, dead spots. What is the MOST likely reason for those spots?

answers.content: Something blocked sunlight or water from reaching those areas.
answers.explanation: Without light or water the grass could not survive, matching lesson concepts.

answers.content: The grass listened to loud music.
The soil turned into sand overnight.
Too much chocolate was dropped there.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT need water to survive?

answers.explanation: Rocks are non-living things, so they do not have a need for water.

questions.question: Most animals get water into their bodies by

answers.explanation: Animals such as monkeys, elephants and humans drink water using their mouths.

answers.content: taking it in through their roots
soaking it up with their fur or feathers

questions.question: Explain how a plant takes in water and moves it to its leaves.

answers.content: A plant absorbs water through its roots, and the water then travels up the stem to the leaves.

questions.question: During the coloured-water investigation, what change do you expect to see in the white flower that stands in the coloured water cup overnight?

answers.content: Its petals will take on the colour of the water.
answers.explanation: The coloured water travels up the stem and tints the petals, showing how water moves through the plant.

answers.content: The flower will wilt because it received no water.

questions.question: Draw and label two different ways you use water every day.

answers.content: Student drawing should show two correct personal uses of water, e.g. drinking and washing.
